key_points: Lifetime's Harry & Meghan: Escaping the Palace premiered, depicting Meghan Markle and Prince Harry's journey leaving royal life.
The movie combines tabloid stories with Harry and Meghan's personal account, covering from after Archie's birth to post-Oprah interview.
It dramatizes events and adds fictional elements to real-life incidents involving the royal couple.
At Trooping the Colour 2019, the film shows the couple's discomfort, a stark contrast to their actual situation according to royal protocol.
Meghan's mental health struggles and suicidal thoughts, shared in the Oprah interview, are paralleled with Princess Diana's experiences in the film.
The movie dramatizes the Sussexes' final royal appearance, suggesting tension and reconciliation among royals not confirmed in real life.
Harry and Meghan's move from Canada to Los Angeles at the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic is covered, including Tyler Perry's assistance.
Despite the Oprah interview being a pivotal event, it was surprisingly underrepresented in the film.
People magazine provides a reality check on these dramatized events, offering insights from sources close to the royals.
The film touches on sensitive topics like mental health, royal family dynamics, and the couple's search for independence.
spokespersons: Sydney Morton (Actor, portrayed Meghan in the movie)
